metadata.case_name: Son of Subbiah Chettiar v. Respondent

facts.text: Appellant is the son of Subbiah Chettiar.
Subbiah Chettiar was adopted by Lakshmi Achi, widow of undivided paternal uncle of respondent, in 1922, becoming coparcener in adoptive family.

Subbiah filed suit for partition of his share, obtained decree; respondent appealed; pending appeal, parties settled amicably; Subbiah received sum and sites, agreed to release all claims including those of his son (appellant).

Appellant filed Civil Suit No. 311 of 1951 on Original Side of Madras High Court for partition of joint family properties and accounts; valued accounts at Rs.1,000 under s.7(iv)(f) paying Rs.112-7-0; partition fixed fee Rs.100 under Art.17-B Sch.II; jurisdiction value Rs.15,00,000.
Registry objected to fees for partition, referred to Master; Master referred to Chamber Judge under s.5; Krishnaswamy Naidu J. on Oct 18,1951 held Art.17-B applies, fees in order.
Respondent filed written statement contending compromise and release deed binding on appellant as fair and bona fide settlement by father as manager.
Ramaswamy Gounder J. tried binding nature as preliminary issue, held settlement bona fide, appellant bound, suit dismissed on Sep 22,1953.
Appellant filed memorandum of appeal on Dec 1,1953 with same fees as plaint.
Registry objected, viewed as s.7(v); Master referred to Taxation Judge under s.12(2); Chief Justice constituted Division Bench, treated as s.5 reference.
Division Bench held Chamber Judge order not final under s.5 (no appointment shown); s.7(v) inapplicable, nor Art.17-B; s.7(iv)(b) applies; direct value partition relief.
Appellant valued partition at Rs.50,000, paid deficit Rs.1,662-7-0, re-presented appeal May 7,1954.
Registry objected: can't value appeal at 50k when plaint jurisdiction 15L without amendment.

Appellant applied Oct 18,1954 to amend plaint to Rs.50,000; opposed by respondent and State; Division Bench rejected, held jurisdiction val binds for fees under s.7(iv)(b); under s.12(2) directed fees on Rs.15,00,000 on plaint and appeal.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave against Division Bench order dated Jan 25,1955.

legal_issues.text: Whether order of Chamber Judge Krishnaswamy Naidu J. on Oct 18,1951 under s.5 Court Fees Act is final.
Whether s.12(2) Court Fees Act applies to appeals from Original Side suits via Madras High Court Fees Rules.
Proper court fee for partition claim: Art.17-B Sch.II, s.7(v), or s.7(iv)(b).
Whether jurisdiction valuation of Rs.15,00,000 in plaint binds for court fees under s.7(iv)(b), or can amend to Rs.50,000.

petitioner_arguments.text: Chamber Judge order final under s.5 as practice in Madras HC to refer to Chamber Judge.
s.12 inapplicable to Original Side appeals.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.3 Court Fees Act; Madras HC Fees Rules O.11 r.1

petitioner_arguments.text: Division Bench order under s.5 final that s.7(iv)(b) applies; valuation Rs.50,000 for fees applies to plaint too; should allow amendment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.7(iv)(b), s.5, s.12 Court Fees Act; s.8 Suits Valuation Act

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise and release by father binding on appellant.
Plaint claim for partition is in substance for possession based on title, fees under s.7(v).
Jurisdiction val Rs.15L binds for fees; no amendment allowed.

court_reasoning.text: No record of appointment of Chamber Judge under s.5, so order not final.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Record does not show general or special order appointing Krishnaswamy Naidu J. under s.5.

court_reasoning.text: Madras HC Fees Rules O.11 r.1 and O.II r.1 extend Chapter III provisions including s.12 to Original Side suits and appeals 'in every other respect'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Logical to apply levy provisions and jurisdiction to check sufficiency including s.12.

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench s.5 order that s.7(iv)(b) applies final, not reopened; s.7(v) and Art.17-B inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff not heard respondent in that reference, but final under s.5.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.7(iv)(b), plaintiff states value for fees; that determines jurisdiction val per s.8 Suits Valuation Act; not vice versa. Liberty to amend plaint valuation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In partition suits, precise valuation difficult; option given; jurisdiction val not bind fees val.

holdings.text: Chamber Judge order not final under s.5 absent appointment record.
s.12 applies to Original Side via Rules.
Fees under s.7(iv)(b); plaintiff valuation for fees primary, determines jurisdiction.
Allow amendment to value relief at Rs.50,000 for fees on plaint and appeal.

precedents_cited.relevance: View that in s.7(iv) cases, allow amendment of plaint to state fees valuation, not bound by jurisdiction val.

statutes_cited.name: Court Fees Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs computation, levy, finality of court fees on plaint and appeal; s.7(iv)(b) allows plaintiff to value partition claim; s.12 allows appellate court to order deficit fees.

statutes_cited.name: Suits Valuation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Value for court fees under s.7(iv) determines jurisdiction value.

statutes_cited.name: Madras High Court Fees Rules, 1933
statutes_cited.relevance: Extends Court Fees Act Chapter III provisions to Original Side suits and appeals.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Madras High Court Division Bench order set aside; appellant permitted to amend plaint to value partition relief at Rs.50,000 under s.7(iv)(b); directed to pay additional court fees on plaint on that basis within two months.
outcome.relief_granted: Liberty to amend plaint valuation; pay fees on Rs.50,000.

key_quotes.text: "the amount stated by the plaintiff as the value of his claim for partition has ordinarily to be accepted by the court in computing the court fees payable in respect of the said relief."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on valuation under s.7(iv)(b).

key_quotes.text: "the value for court fees and the value for jurisdiction must no doubt be the same in such cases but it is the value for court fees stated by the plaintiff that is of primary importance."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies primacy of fees valuation over jurisdiction val.

key_quotes.text: "It would not be reasonable or proper in such a case to hold the plaintiff bound by the valuation made by him for the purposes of jurisdiction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
